column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Our operated assets manage waste to meet site-specific waste management plans, Whitehaven's waste management standard and state and federal environmental regulatory requirements. We segregate, store, transport and dispose of waste to mitigate the risk of adverse environmental impacts.
column20: Waste management, environment, regulatory requirements

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: While mineral waste is typically non-hazardous, we undertake geochemical tests to determine if it presents any risks as a source of pollution. Where such risks are identified, mineral waste is monitored and managed as required under our approvals to ensure appropriate encapsulation and non-polluting outcomes are achieved.
column20: Risk, pollution, mineral waste

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Hazardous waste is classified, managed and disposed of by relevant Australian Standards and regulatory requirements and is periodically removed from our operations by licensed contractors. The primary dangerous waste our operations generate is all recycled waste oils.
column20: Hazardous, waste, classification

column6: Waste generated
column7: 6.6kt non hazardous and 2.7kt hazardous waste generated

column6: Waste diverted from disposal
column7: 60% is non-mineral waste recycled, and 100% is hazardous waste recycled.

column6: Waste directed to disposal
column7: Coal projects (tailings) are co-disposed within overburden emplacements at each relevant mine site. The waste emplacements are appropriately designed by internal and third-party subject matter experts, managed to be safe, stable, and non-polluting, and are progressively shaped by dozers to enable land rehabilitation.

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
column13: Our environmental management approach focuses on mitigating unavoidable impacts, rehabilitating disturbed areas, and offsetting residual effects that cannot be addressed. Our operational sites and development projects must adhere to our organisation-wide environmental management standards and procedures, site-specific commitments and regulatory requirements.
column20: Environmental impact mitigation, Habitat restoration, Biodiversity preservation

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: In FY23, we completed due diligence on our key third-party labour-hire providers through a comprehensive self-assessment questionnaire. In all cases, we found no evidence of modern slavery practices in our supply chain.
column20: Modern slavery due diligence, Supply chain scrutiny, Ethical business practices

column6: Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Our Graduate Program is a two-year development pathway that delivers a rich learning environment for graduates from various disciplines. This program builds their technical skills and core capabilities through on-the-job experience and formal development sessions.
column20: Graduate Program development, Talent cultivation, Employee training

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Our Employee Referral Policy, introduced in FY22 and incentivises existing staff to refer new talent to the business, successfully attracted several new employees during the year.
column20: Employee Referral Policy implementation, Talent acquisition, Staff recruitment

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: The most recent survey results showed our engagement level increased by 5% to 6.6 out of 10 (compared to the prior year). We had a survey participation rate of 62%. The sentiment of our workforce improved about goal setting, which means our people are clear about their priorities and why their work is essential. Management support and recognition reflect the positive impact of our STRIVE Values reward and recognition program.
column20: Employee engagement survey results, Workforce sentiment, Organisational culture

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
Parental leave
column13: Recognising the importance of parental leave in supporting equality and attracting talent, we introduced an industry-leading paid parental leave policy in FY22 that includes 26 weeks of paid leave for primary carers and superannuation on unpaid portions of leave.
column20: Paid parental leave policy, Workplace equality, Talent attraction

column6: Parental leave
column13: We continue to improve our understanding of workplace re-engagement hurdles. We are re-designing our policies to ensure we offer primary carers the pathway to return to their career and the opportunity to thrive. One such initiative is the 'There's No Barrier to Part-Time' program, which provides flexibility when our people need it most.
column20: Return-to-work programs, Career re-engagement, Workforce flexibility

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Our people's health, safety, and wellbeing are priorities, and we strive to improve our approach and outcomes continuously. Our five-year Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) strategy and critical objectives, set in FY21, underpin our key focus areas. The broadened set of leading safety indicators introduced last year promotes visible safety leadership and coaching in the field. It applies a risk-based lens to serious injury prevention by focusing on reporting and learning from incidents that have the potential to result in serious harm. This further embeds a positive safety culture.
column20: Wellbeing, approach, health and safety

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Our approach to health and safety is risk-based, pragmatic, and oriented to areas we can positively impact. We work to systematically identify, assess, report and rectify health and safety hazards that have the potential to cause single or multiple fatalities. We focus on the controls that are most critical to the health and safety of our people.
column20: Identification, assessment, report

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Our approach to critical control management is consistent with the International Council of Mining and Metals' Health & Safety Critical Control Management Ã¢ÂÂ Good Practice Guide. Each operating site's health and safety system must meet our organisation-wide minimum requirements, as defined by our policies, standards and procedures. A standardised HSE reporting system and assurance program supports our system.
column20: Critical control management, HSE, International Council

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: We are focused on strengthening our identification and investigation of safety hazards and incidents that can be precursors to significant incidents by applying learnings to prevent future failures. It includes adopting a consistent risk-based decision-making approach where material risks are identified, controlled and verified using a consistent and aligned organisation-wide approach.\t
column20: Risk-based safety approach, Hazard identification, Safety controls

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: We strive to reduce psychological hazards in our workplace, build a culture of resilience, and equip our people with positive coping strategies to manage their health and wellbeing. We do this through ongoing education of our leaders and workforce, emphasising the importance of mental wellness and healthy lifestyle choices.
column20: Mental wellness initiatives, Psychological hazard reduction, Resilience building

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
Occupational health services
column13: The Complete Miner is our holistic health and wellbeing program. It aims to increase awareness of risk behaviours, motivate people to make positive change and facilitate connections to resources supporting health and wellbeing goals.
column20: Communication platform launch, Recognition initiative, Workforce engagement

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: The Safehaven Conference Ã¢ÂÂ which we have hosted every year since 2015 Ã¢ÂÂ is a key annual event that enables us to collaborate on our annual HSE strategic plans and build safety leadership capability. This initiative continues to improve and grow. With about 200 conference attendees annually, including employees, contractors and business partners, it provides a valuable opportunity for meaningful engagement and consultation to share and learn from successes and challenges and integrate improvements in our operations.
column20: Mental fitness partnership, Prevention focus, Early intervention

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: The vehicle hierarchy road rule training initiative was delivered through strong engagement with our workforce at all levels of operation. We provided training, awareness and coaching sessions to foster change and establish an influential learning culture.
column20: Performance measurement systems, Information integrity, Quality assurance

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: To support worker management of personal fatigue and risk factors, in FY23, we delivered whole-of-workforce training on fatigue management by an external subject-matter expert. Several further fatigue-related improvement strategies are planned for FY24, including journey management, fatigue assessments, targeted frontline leader awareness sessions and further access to sleep studies.\t
column20: Vehicle hierarchy road rules, Fatigue risk reduction, Injury prevention

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: In FY23, more than 40 leaders participated in our bespoke Mental Health First Aid Program, which we developed in partnership with our employee assistance provider. This program educates our leaders in identifying and managing psychological hazards in the workplace and helps them support team members who may be struggling with their wellbeing.
column20: Fatigue management system, Health risk identification, Proactive intervention

column6: Promotion of worker health
column8: Culture on wellbeing and psychological safety
column13: We are committed to developing a more robust, more mature HSE culture and aim to be an industry leader in caring for the health and wellbeing of our people. Our areas of work focus on shifting from a compliance-based culture to one where our people feel psychologically safe, and there is mutual ownership and accountability for HSE outcomes, along with a commitment to safety leadership, engagement and care.
column20: HSE culture development, Safety leadership, Accountability

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: A new communication and rewards platform, WHC Connects, was also launched in conjunction with the STRIVE Awards in response to the request for improved communication and recognition. The platform includes workforce communications, health and wellbeing information, and resources.

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: During FY23, we implemented vehicle hierarchy road rules at our Tarrawonga Mine after introducing this at Maules Creek the prior year. The vehicle hierarchy road rules are based on a system where vehicles lower on the hierarchy, such as passenger vehicles, give way to cars higher up the hierarchy.

column8: Vehicle risk related to fatigue and distraction reduction
column13: The system supports injury risk reduction associated with fatigue by alerting the operator using an audible tone and seat vibration, providing early identification of a tired worker and enabling immediate actions. The system also supports prevention by improving workers' management of personal fatigue and identifying potential health or lifestyle risk factors, resulting in proactive worker health risk management.
